Jason Hawreliak: Students can receive a certificate in Digital Media by completing the following courses:
Michael Gicante: * Indicates a primary offering of a cross listed course

Jason Hawreliak: IASC 1F01
Michael Gicante: Foundations of Interactive Arts and Science

Jason Hawreliak: Conceptual frameworks for interactive media technology, design, theory and production. Focus on digital scholarship, expression, prototyping, and instructional design. Practice-based projects leading to the development of an interactive media product.
Michael Gicante: Restriction: open to IASC (single or combined), IASC/BEd (junior Intermediate) majors or permission of the Centre.

Jason Hawreliak: Note: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.
Michael Gicante: IASC 1F02

Jason Hawreliak: Being Human in a Digital World
Michael Gicante: Exploration of how emerging technologies shape human identities and lifestyles. Impact of rapid technological change on citizenship, education, employment, entertainment, globalization, health, privacy and security. Predictions of what the future may hold and its implications for the human condition.

Jason Hawreliak: Restriction: open to IASC (single or combined) majors, IASC/BEd (junior Intermediate) until date specified in Registration guide. In Spring session open to all students.

Michael Gicante: IASC 1P04

Jason Hawreliak: New Media and Games
Michael Gicante: Information, knowledge, and expression in interactive and networked media environments. Technologies and socio-political infrastructures that make such media possible. Historical development of and precedents for interactive media. Concepts in poetics, hypertextuality, hypermediacy, remediation, social relations and play. Projects that build active participation in new media cultures.

Michael Gicante: IASC 1P10

Jason Hawreliak: Introduction to Media Tools
Michael Gicante: Systematic examination of imaging, multimedia authoring and animation software tools and their application to problems in visualization, representation and sequencing of image, text, video and audio content. Portfolio development emphasizes conceptualization and reflection in new media contexts.

Jason Hawreliak: Restriction: open to IASC (single or combined) majors until date specified in Registration guide.
Michael Gicante: Note: enrolment limited to 24 students. This course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

Jason Hawreliak: *IASC 1P30
Michael Gicante: Programming for Interactive Media

Jason Hawreliak: Introduction to contemporary programming syntax including classes, functions, properties and events for developing interactive media applications.
Michael Gicante: Note: enrolment limited to 60 students. This course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

Jason Hawreliak: #IASC 1P50
Michael Gicante: Integrity and Literacy in the Information Age

Jason Hawreliak: Issues in use of information technology including historic and social perspectives; legal, ethical and moral issues; intellectual property, licensing and copyright; privacy and freedom of expression; professional conduct and information literacy.
Michael Gicante: Note: this course involves seminars and considerable written work. A good command of written and spoken English is required. This course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

Jason Hawreliak: #IASC 1P93
Michael Gicante: Applied Programming

Jason Hawreliak: Modern software techniques including problem solving and design of effective algorithms, structured program design methodology, subprogram library usage, documentation, correctness, floating-point arithmetic and error analysis.
Michael Gicante: Note: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

Jason Hawreliak: #IASC 1P95
Michael Gicante: Digital Foundation

Jason Hawreliak: Technical foundations of digital images, media methods and concepts including web-based, digital photography, image processing software and printing; foundations of digital media in video, audio and computational production and post-production. Contemporary digital practices within the broader history of visual and media arts.
Michael Gicante: Note: students will need additional materials, which they must supply. Field trips may be required. Students are expected to pay their own expenses. Due to space limitations, audits are not permitted in studio classes. This course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

Jason Hawreliak: #IASC 1P96
Michael Gicante: Studio Foundation

Jason Hawreliak: Basic aesthetic and conceptual processes that underlie visual art production. Two- and three-dimensional formal principles, fundamental critical issues and stylistic/material development. Examples from historic and contemporary art practice provide context for studio projects and readings.
Michael Gicante: #IASC 1P99

Jason Hawreliak: The Culture of Noise
Michael Gicante: Role of noise in music, social space and art. Exploration of discursive issues concerning the value of sound studies.

Jason Hawreliak: Note: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.
Michael Gicante: #IASC 1Q98

Jason Hawreliak: Introduction to Visual Culture
Michael Gicante: Overview of visual culture, its vocabulary, technologies and structures within varied cultural contexts. Problems of meaning, functions of visual culture in contemporary society, the role of galleries and museums, and the impact of imagery in advertising, popular media and consumer culture. Contemporary critical methodology.

Jason Hawreliak: Note: no studio work. Field trips may be required. Students are expected to pay their own expenses. This course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.
Michael Gicante: #IASC 1Q99

Jason Hawreliak: Contemporary Issues in The History of Western Art
Michael Gicante: Analysis of key issues in the history of Western art, including various ways of looking at the visual past and present. Focus on the visual arts from prehistory through the early 20th century.

Jason Hawreliak: Note: no studio work. Field trips may be required. Students are expected to pay their own expenses. This course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.
Michael Gicante: #IASC 2F27

Jason Hawreliak: Historical Geographic Information Systems
Michael Gicante: Overview of multiple fields in history in which Geographic Information Systems are applied. Instruction in use of software and provides local history project for students to apply software skills

Jason Hawreliak: Note: labs focus on the history of St. Catharines. This course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.
Michael Gicante: IASC 2P01

Jason Hawreliak: Foundations of Project Management
Michael Gicante: Professional strategies for planning and managing projects from inception to closure. Managing risks and constraints. Promoting collaboration and communication. Time management strategies for individuals and project teams. Solutions to common project management challenges. Introduction to project management software and organizers.

Jason Hawreliak: Restriction: open to IASC (single or combined), IASC/BEd (junior Intermediate) majors until date specified in Registration guide. Students must have a minimum of 5.0 overall credits. In Spring session open to all students with a minimum of 5.0 overall credits.
Michael Gicante: Note: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

Jason Hawreliak: IASC 2P02
Michael Gicante: Solving Problems through Interactive Arts and Science

Jason Hawreliak: Role of digital tools in addressing scholarly questions in the humanities. Case studies, current trends and critical debates.
Michael Gicante: Restriction: open to IASC (single or combined) majors or permission of the Centre.

Jason Hawreliak: Note: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.
Michael Gicante: IASC 2P03

Jason Hawreliak: Interaction and Interface Design
Michael Gicante: Composition and interface design for reactive and interactive systems. Layout, graphics and media tools for user interface design. Models for how interactivity shapes understanding and expectations of digital media tools and interfaces.

Jason Hawreliak: Restriction: open to IASC (single or combined), IASC/BEd (junior Intermediate) majors until date specified in Registration guide.
Michael Gicante: Note: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

Jason Hawreliak: IASC 2P04
Michael Gicante: Ludology

Jason Hawreliak: Nature, psychology and characteristics of play. Theories related to fun, play and games including improvisation, competition, exploration, role-playing, sports and thrill-seeking. Examination of formal and informal games, goals, rules, decisions, interaction, rewards and penalties, and psychological triggers and responses. Analysis of gameplay, player experience, engagement, mechanics, design and usability.
Michael Gicante: Note: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

Jason Hawreliak: IASC 2P05
Michael Gicante: Game Design Paradigms

Jason Hawreliak: Conceptual and practical frameworks for the design of games as systems. Consideration of the formal structures of games. Focus on world building and narrative, goals and experience, balance, consistency, and meaningful decision making. Simple game prototyping, testing and documentation.
Michael Gicante: Note: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

Jason Hawreliak: IASC 2P06
Michael Gicante: 3D Objects, Environments and Visualization

Jason Hawreliak: Introduction to concepts and tools for 3D modelling, texturing, lighting, cameras, and navigation for the production of virtual spaces and mixed-reality environments. Contemporary perspectives on the simulation and representation of 3D spaces in a humanities context. Introduction to 3D scanning and printing.
Michael Gicante: Restriction: open to IASC (single or combined) majors until date specified in Registration guide.

Jason Hawreliak: Note: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.
Michael Gicante: #IASC 2P07

Jason Hawreliak: Introduction to Geospatial Technologies
Michael Gicante: Concepts and applications of geographic information systems (GIS), global positioning systems (GPS) and remote sensing. Properties of digital maps, airborne data and satellite imagery. Principles of map compilation and design. Practical experience in computer mapping, image interpretation and GIS analysis.

Jason Hawreliak: Note: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

Jason Hawreliak: Competencies in Interactive Arts and Science
Michael Gicante: Workshops, conferences, networking events, volunteer opportunities and other experiences related to the Interactive Arts and Science program.

Michael Gicante: Inner workings of modern computers from a user's point of view. Understanding the hardware, network and system software. Topics include CPUs, memory, video, input/output, networks, security, installation of operating systems and hands-on trouble shooting.
